It signifies preserved dynamic neuromodulation rather than proof of any direct association of alpha with conscious awareness. Otherwise alpha activity doesn't reliably differentiate between VS and MCS (163). It remains likely however, that EEG markers can discriminate severity of disordered conscious states and in those studies that don't, it may simply be that inadequate clinical criteria were used (164,165). Baseline amplitude, frequency reactivity and change at 6 months are better indices of outcome.

Contrary to findings in VS, lower alpha was associated with covert conscious awareness in MCS, fitting the general assumption that alpha activity is not an index of awareness per se. A study did show some spindles during NREM sleep in MCS, but not VS suggesting NREM cycle unmasks a preserved component of cholinergic function (166). MAB states that relative disruption of basal forebrain output as compared to brainstem function in MCS and VS patients reduces alpha, but preserves consciousness. Conversely, recovery from VS correlates with increased ARAS (specifically the intralaminar thalamus) connectivity to the basal forebrain, parietal lobe and prefrontal cortex based on diffusion tensor tractography (167,168). VS and MCS are common sequelae after traumatic brain injury (TBI) and human and animal studies show cortical cholinergic deficits and basal forebrain damage, which appears to be relatively selective (169)(170)(171)(172)(173)(174). Monoaminergic and brainstem cholinergic nuclei are often spared in TBI (175). This is consistent with a recent study suggesting that up to a quarter of unresponsive people with brain injuries may be conscious (176).

Studies in dementing brain disorders show a direct correlation between decline in cholinergic activity and reduced alpha. Association of reduced alpha power with degenerative changes in cholinergic white matter tracts (177) and poor alpha reactivity (178) has been demonstrated in Alzheimer patients. Lewy body dementia (LBD) is marked by early and more severe deficits in cholinergic function and corresponding loss of forebrain neurons (179)(180)(181). Indeed, in one study of patients with LBD, one third had no posterior alpha, and slowing of the mean dominant rhythm overall. REM sleep behaviour disorder (where cholinergic activity is normally comparable to waking) progressed from 60 to above 90 percent of subjects on reassessment over time (182). These changes correspond to loss of alpha as the dominant rhythm and increased frontal intermittent rhythmic delta activity (183,184). Other studies show improvement on some measures of arousal by deep brain stimulation of intralaminar thalamus, including what might be considered stereotypical behaviour, bilateral hemisphere recovery of alpha rhythms and disappearance of delta waves (185,186). These changes can be conveniently explained by enhanced cholinergic modulation of cortical networks. The intralaminar thalamus projects to cholinergic interneurons of the striatum (187,188) and is part of the putative anatomical substrate of implicit cognition 7 .

Several caveats need addressing as regards to the sensitivity and specificity during an EEG assessment of awareness after TBI, including widespread compromise of white matter tracts interconnecting cortical areas, of which coherent states are presumed important. This is amply illustrated by the finding that cortical activation in a vegetative state is often limited to primary regions and dissociated from higher-order cortices (189). Secondly EEG slow waves are an indirect measure of preserved pharmacological mechanisms of awareness i.e. MAB predicts that alpha and delta rhythms represent negative indices of respective conscious and subconscious processing. Gamma rhythms are a feature of disorders of consciousness (190) and should prefigure in any theory of covert awareness. Furthermore, conscious memory of events during behavioural unresponsiveness (191) is contingent on reactive monoaminergic and especially serotonergic activity (through Gq/11 receptors) and this in summary, is what is indirectly indexed by persistent delta activity, which itself presumably a direct index of activity at Gi/o receptors. The paradigm is supported by enhanced explicit memory correlates with increased slow delta and reduced alpha activity during quiet rest (192).

div.head: Appendix B: Plasticity and Consolidation of Memories
Interaction of noradrenergic and cholinergic systems in remodelling and consolidation of memories
div.p: A number of studies support the critical role of neuromodulators in memory encoding and consolidation. Dynamic regulation of subcortical cholinergic and monoaminergic nuclei above baseline levels is confirmed by a study looking at LTP in hippocampal slices (193). LTP was not induced individually by low doses of the b-agonist isoproterenol or cholinergic receptor agonist carbachol, but was effective when combined. Furthermore, some receptor subtypes involved in catecholaminergic and cholinergic muscarinic interactions i.e. between b-noradrenergic and muscarinic M1 receptors, are reinforcing and assist in remodelling the prepotent aversive response.

A transient increase in locus coeruleus (LC) activity during SWS occurred 2 hours postlearning of an olfactory discrimination task and also after extinction (194). This was interpreted as evidence for noradrenergic consolidation of memory. However, optogenetic stimulation of the locus coeruleus during both SWS and REM sleep reduced NREM (non REM) spindles and disrupted consolidation of a hippocampus-dependent food location learning task (195). Artificial LC activation impaired both new learning and familiar task consolidation. MAB explains these findings by considering the necessity of alternating NREM spindle and noradrenergic (NA) neuromodulation as the process of remodelling. Spindling indexes and indirectly exposes recent implicitly learned tasks that are enhanced by cholinergic activation (unmasked by brief drops in monoamine activity during NREM sleep). Noradrenergic phasic increases that terminate spindling enhance remodelling. In other words, prepotent implicit networks must first be activated for remodelling and consolidation of a highlighted network or learned procedure to occur. This interpretation of alternating neuromodulator balance fits the recurring sleep cycles between NREM and REM sleep, during which SWS becomes less prevalent later in the night and also the importance of ongoing sleep spindles and Stage 2 sleep throughout in procedural task consolidation (196). Activation of LC during REM sleep interfered with consolidation based on implicit or procedural measures (195). This study was unusual in not disambiguating NA increases on memory consolidation during both NREM and REM sleep. The methodology antagonised all cholinergic mediated activity during sleep and continued to maintain the plasticity potential of place fields. This interpretation is consistent with normal consolidation of a radial maze with ripple-triggered low frequency stimulation of the LC confined to SWS in a study mimicking activity during normal sleep (197).

Engagement of the noradrenergic system is important for cognitive flexibility (198). Evidence for this comes from tasks in monkeys where, after habituation associated with a reduction in NA activity, a sudden change in behavioural contingency induces phasic increases in NA activity (199). However, unlike the hypothesis that high levels of NA activity increase distractibility as a mechanism for adaptation proposed by (198), MAB suggests greater parsimony of NA inhibition, not just reinforcement of putative cholinergically-dependent prepotent behaviours. This is more consistent with the use of drugs with pharmacological properties of catecholamines in maintaining focussed activities i.e. inhibiting distractions.

Remodelling is generally couched in terms of potentiation and depotentiation correlating to phasic expression or silencing of NA activity, respectively. However, this does not capture the full complexity of the findings. The reversal tasks in monkeys showed a shift in NA to the new target (old ignored target) well ahead of a behavioural switch and extinction of the old target response took much longer than NA depotentiation (199). In rats LC activity was present in the context of both the conditioning and negative predictor in an aversive paradigm, but both disappeared once the behaviour was established (200). This leaves room for the concept of neuromodulation by an alternative system that is related to consolidation of prepotent or automatic behaviours, i.e. cholinergic muscarinic modulation, and the difficulty in remodelling these traces can lead to maladaptive behaviours.

div.head: Sharp wave ripples (SWR)
div.p: As claimed by MAB, spindles are an indirect index of implicit cognitive events. So, what parallel signal traces might actually be highlighted during SWS that are subsequently modified by monoaminergic activity? Most spindles are temporally correlated with hippocampal sharp wave ripples, which are synchronized high gamma frequency bursts of neurons and are typically seen during NREM sleep (38). CA1 pyramidal cell activity underlies SWR and concurrent high frequency oscillations are also present in the neocortex (36). Rodent hippocampal ripples are often associated with replay of place cells that were present during learning, sometimes in novel combinations suggesting not just consolidation of previously learned behaviour, but a dynamic remodelling (201). Noradrenergic activity suppresses SWR in an in vivo hippocampal rat study, but a rebound increase of SWR activity followed with washout (202). The inhibitory and facilitatory effects are mediated by a1 (some activity at a2) and b receptors, respectively. This is a classic description of a dual mode of action in the MAB model.

div.head: The hippocampus as conductor and the cortex as its orchestra: a new order
div.p: A contentious note regarding the role of the hippocampus in memory. Graded retrograde amnesia and loss of anterograde declarative memories after hippocampal lesions led to the belief that memories were initial encoded in the hippocampus and then gradually transferred to the neocortex for consolidation, although this was supplanted by a multi-trace theory with further consolidation or transformation dependent on ongoing hippocampal-neocortical interactions. Remarkably this is still the enduring accepted paradigm. A number of technical problems and inconsistencies beset the present iterations of the model that are raised by even proponents of the theory. The most difficult issue for the so-called slow transfer of information is the great deal of variability in time from initial encoding to cortical independence, which can even occur immediately after training. A good summary of proposed processes and some of their limitations can be found in (203).

One commonly discussed idea is the correlation between hippocampal ripples and fast cortical oscillations mediating transfer of information (36). However, such correlations already assume pre-existent traces and further rely on solely Hebbian mechanisms of a transfer that are ill-defined and unsupported. Furthermore, long term potentiation (LTP) in in vivo hippocampal slices use more vigorous high frequency stimulation (HFS) protocols than short infrequent bursts of SWR (30-200 msec) and late LTP requires neuromodulation (204). b-adrenoceptor agonism enhances LTP even at subthreshold HFS by recruiting translation of mRNAs (205).

A second, albeit less dominant body of work, demonstrated strong evidence for neuromodulation in consolidating initial encoding by cholinergic and monoaminergic systems (206,207). These two approaches to memory were brought into parsimony by the proposition of hippocampal rhythmicity triggering phasic activation of corticopetal monoaminergic nuclei (114). Further consolidation occurs during sleep related modulation by monoaminergic and cholinergic systems (41). The relative predominance of particular neurotransmitters have distinct signatures during REM and NREM sleep. Phasic activity of neuromodulators reinforce concurrent cortical sensory activity, coactivity acting to select for synaptic strengthening. Indeed, the limbic and paralimbic structures were first conceived by this author in their roles as modulators of dual cholinergic and monoaminergic system in a more recent paper (208). The model presents a more elegant solution to systems consolidation than the concept of direct transfer of information and the confounding issues of strict timing and precedent activity. The model has the advantage that it doesn't require duplicate memory traces. The hippocampus has its own unique and permanent spatial memory repository, a finding that presents another anomaly for the temporary storage theory.

The author also proposes a new and original re-conception of hippocampal remodelling and consolidation of neocortical traces based on this mechanism of subcortical neuromodulation. According to this theory, the perforant pathway to the dentate gyrus and mossy projection fibres from granule cells to the CA3 hippocampal subdivision generates neuromodulator activating rhythmicity of DR and LC. Support for the standard model described above comes from work where optogenetic activation of dentate neurons evokes fear memory recall (209). The gradual fading with time of dentate engram cells and concurrent persistence in basolateral amygdala and prefrontal cortex is consistent with shifting of remote memories from the hippocampus, although the mechanism was unclear (210). The standard model claims that dentate engram cells are required to recall behaviour through direct projections to the cortex. The present hypothesis is antithetical i.e. the initial persistence of a dentate engram during elicited fear behaviour continues to coactivate brainstem neuromodulators, that in turn helps consolidate and remodel cortical networks. The model emphasizes engram activity by the nature of its subcortical, not cortical projections. The current model states that initial engrams for consolidation are distributed throughout the cortex from the outset rather than first forming a hippocampal repository. The hippocampus has a unique role in permanently storing spatial memory engrams, but it has a further primary and parallel role in generating rhythmic phasic activation of brainstem monoaminergic nuclei that modulate cortical networks in systems consolidating declarative memories i.e. indirect mechanism of consolidation rather than direct transfer of information.

Implicit and explicit traces in CA1 and surrounding subiculum are long term. They are important for autobiographical context and spatial memories are stored there. Thus, they are more immutable for highly accurate performance, but can adaptively shift to other structures (211). Nonetheless, if the dentate is to perform flexibly with ongoing memory formation in novel contextual contingencies throughout the life of an individual, then even covert links might ultimately be supplanted. Is there evidence for this? Neurogenesis is an active area of pursuit (212)(213)(214), where adult granule cells establish synapses with hilar interneurons, mossy cells and CA3 pyramidal cells (215). There is evidence for adult rat neurogenesis in newly acquired trace memories (216).

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: Dynamics of the EEG spectrogram during induction and emergence from propofol-induced unconsciousness. (A) Group-level click (blue, Pclicks) and verbal (red, Pverbal) response-probability curves, as shown previously in Fig. 1D. (B) Group-level baseline-normalized spectrograms from a frontal channel (approximately Fz, nearest-neighbor Laplacian reference) aligned with respect to LOC and ROC. The white contour circumscribes the regions where power differs significantly from baseline (P < 0.05, sign test) and indicates significant increases in power spanning low-frequency (0.1-1Hz) through gamma (25-35 Hz) bands. (C) Group-level time course of power in lowfrequency, alpha (8-12 Hz), and gamma bands aligned with respect to LOC and ROC. (D) Grouplevel spatial distribution of low frequency alpha, and gamma power during unconsciousness (LOC + 15 min). Permission from Purdon et al., 2013.

figure.head: Figure 3 .
figure.figDesc: Spectral patterns at the end of maintenance under sevoflurane general anesthesia comprise 4 basic patterns.

figure.head: Figure 4 .
figure.figDesc: Illustrative electroencephalogram (EEG) spectrogram of a healthy volunteer during induction and emergence from sevoflurane-induced unconsciousness. (A) End tidal sevoflurane concentration during induction and emergence. (B) Behavioral stimuli response-probability curve corresponding to (A). (C) EEG spectrograms from a frontal channel (approximately Fz) corresponding to (A,B) above show that sevoflurane-induced oscillatory dynamics are closely associated with altered arousal. (D) Zoomed in spectrogram during effect-onset and -offset. (E)Binary response demonstrates that loss of awake-alpha is correlated with lack of response (red) to behavioral stimuli(11).

figure.head: Opioids
figure.figDesc: Opioids are often used to supplement general anaesthesia believed to reduce arousal to noxious stimuli such as during surgical procedures by direct actions on the spinal cord. A major pathway of action of the opioid receptors is Gbg activation of GIRKs (106) that might act through confluent pathways on the brain to enhance slow rhythms. Fentanyl in humans causes high voltage delta waves and alfentanil in dogs induces in addition high alpha at the peak of delta waves during surgical levels of anaesthesia (figure 5)(107,108).

figure.head: Figure 5 .
figure.figDesc: Neocortical EEG activity (FT, fronto-temporal; TC, temporo-central) in a dog at 5 min before ( = baseline), and 2 and 5 min after onset of a constant i.v. infusion of 0.016 mg/kg/min alfentanil. Within 2 min, baseline low voltage high frequency activity (20-25 Hz, 50-350 #V)

figure.head: Figure 6 .
figure.figDesc: Changes in a raw EEG trace of dexmedetomidine sedation and propofol sedation from channel Fz. WA, wakefulness; MS, moderate sedation; DS, deep sedation; RS, recovery state (RS). During MS and DS, the EEG differences between the two agents are obvious.

figure.head: Figure 7 .
figure.figDesc: Illustrative spectrogram showing the evolution of ketamine anesthesia electroencephalogram signatures. At time point A, 2 mg of midazolam and 100mcg of fentanyl were administered. At time point B, 200 mg of ketamine was administered to induce general anesthesia.

figure.head: Figure 8 .
figure.figDesc: Trends in the spectrum and coherence from 18 to 90 yr old during propofol anaesthesia. (A) The frontal EEG spectrum as a function of age. Slow (0.1-1 Hz) oscillations are present in all patients during general anaesthesia maintained solely with propofol. Alpha (8-12 Hz) oscillations appear to diminish with age. (B) The trend in alpha power appears to decrease with age. The green line represents a linear regression model describing the relationship between age and alpha power.

figure.head: Figure 9 .
figure.figDesc: Predominant frontal slowing following painful stimulation(152).

figure.head: Figure 10 .
figure.figDesc: Examples of EEG spindles in natural sleep (A), and during general anaesthesia with desflurane and fentanyl (B and C). All were obtained using a pre-frontal electrode montage. Note the prominent background delta activity in 1A and 1B. Permission from(155).

figure.head: Figure 11 .
figure.figDesc: Example of an EEG spectrogram around the end of an operation under desflurane and remifentanil. At the left of the diagram (from 0 to w150 sec) a decrease in volatile anaesthetic concentration results in an obvious decrease in the spindle activity (peak frequency 9.5 Hz). At 260 sec the patient shows a sudden increase in high frequencies, consistent with return of EMG tone, but does not start responding to verbal command until the 290 sec mark. Permission from(155). Of potential interest here is the relative decrement in alpha spindling compared to delta.

body.note: This is contrary to the accepted wisdom which focuses on slow wave windows of gamma waves and phase coupling assuming a direct correlation of nested rhythms to slow wave activity. Given the EEG confounds the spatial segregation of observed rhythms, the alternative interpretation can only be approached through theoretical models.2 A tonal frequency discrimination study during anaesthesia demonstrated greater than zero P300 and N100 for hits at preinduction and were not significantly above zero during surgery(14). However, both ERP markers were absent during hits in a minority of subjects during emergence only. One ought to refrain from considering any marker of cognitive process as an absolute or equivalent correspondence to time definitions of ERPs i.e. N100 and P300., but view them as consistent, if not powerful indices only, and that they can vary under different neurophysiological conditions. For example, the hits during emergence demonstrated a biphasic waveform similar to N100/P300 but at 500-600ms. Reaction times for hits increased by ~300ms, which corresponds to the observed latency increases in corresponding ERPs. In other words, ERP markers may not have been absent all, but longer latency due to delayed anaesthetic recovery.

The task of differentiating the many sources of gamma activity and establishing their varied significance is not straightforward. It remains fortuitous that the two signals representing dual cognitive inhibition, as proposed by the MAB hypothesis, coalesce around separate slow spectral bands, delta and alpha, suggesting a link to common neuromodulation through different receptor subtypes.4 Much more can be said here about what is necessary and sufficient in a theory predicting a conscious phenomenology beyond electrophysiological markers such as EEG, complexity and pharmacology. Postulates

Interestingly the authors, using dual thalamic and cortical electrodes, claimed to find evidence for thalamic origin to spindles based on thalamocortical progression of the signal, but this was only illustrated for about half of the trials leaving open the question of an independent cortical source of spindle generation.

Descriptions of hippocampal theta were best correlated to behaviours in rat models. Theta doesn't quite have the same privileged position in primates with beta and gamma being quite prominent outside of early-stage sleep(126). The idea is the same, in principle however i.e. of active engagement of monoaminergic nuclei by recurrent hippocampal activity entrained by the dentate gyrus.

i.e. part of the aforementioned parallel cognitive unconscious that is hypothesized to mediate instantiation of implicit algorithms on habit forming repertoires and mediating unconscious components of motor efference learning. Motor efference copy is an important non pharmacological model resolving aspects of the mind-body problem and part of the enactive theory canon that can determine the nature of acquired algorithms that discriminate between conscious and unconscious cognition. The ideas are referenced earlier and beyond the scope of the current paper.
